Award.AwardTitle: Defining the Plant Cell Wall Xyloglucan Biosynthetic Complex Localized in Golgi

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit. Xyloglucan, a hemicellulose, is a major component of the primary cell wall of many plants and provides important structural and physiological functions. With the exception of cellulose, xyloglucan is the best characterized cell wall polysaccharide, and considerable progress has been made to identify and characterize the enzymes involved in its synthesis. Recently, six Golgi-localized transferase enzymes were shown to be involved in xyloglucan formation. However, the functional organization and regulation of these enzymes in the Golgi membrane is currently unknown. Preliminary research for this project found distinct hierarchal roles among three of the enzymes and demonstrated that all six interact in pair-wise fashion with each other. The scientific goal of this project is to define the structural organization and functional regulation of this multi-enzyme complex during the synthesis of xyloglucan in the plant cell in the model species, Arabidopsis thaliana. Research results will help to establish the mechanistic basis for the functional organization of the polysaccharide biosynthetic machinery localized in the Golgi complex of this and other plant species.

Broader Impacts. The outcome of the project will facilitate the engineering of plants to produce hemicelluloses with modified properties that will enhance development and protection against environmental stress, and will increase industrial interest in the use of plant polysaccharides. This research will be accomplished in collaboration with Michigan State University and University of California at Riverside. The collaboration will create broad opportunities and an outstanding environment for undergraduate and graduate students to be trained through a combined program of biochemistry, cell, and molecular biology. Undergraduate students will be recruited through the Iowa State University Summer Undergraduate Research Programs and the Program for Women in Science and Engineering. A six-week summer research experience will be provided for one intern each year. The project will also include a collaboration with the Iowa State University Extension to convey scientific information on plant biomass composition, formation, and modification to local biomass growers, land managers and the general public through participation in annual workshops and the creation of an internet webpage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcome of the project is the demonstration, for the first time, that the efficient biosynthesis of the plant branched polysaccharide requires a multiprotein complex specifically organized within Golgi apparatus. Using cell biology, molecular biology, structural biology, and biochemical approaches, we demonstrated that the glucan synthase, three xylosyltransferases, two galactosyltransferases and fucosyltransferase form the complex via multiple surface interactions within Golgi lumen as well as through transmembrane domains localized in Golgi membrane. Formation of several core heterodimers among glucan synthase and six glycosyltransferases revealed in this study suggests that glycosyltransferases are all organized around glucan synthase and, most likely, sequentially decorate glucan backbone while it is synthesized. Among these key heterodimers, the dimers formed between three xylosyltransferases, XXT1-XXT2 and XXT2-XXT5 were proposed to be essential for complete glucan backbone xylosylation. However, the specific contribution of XXT5 was unclear until we obtained the crystal structure of XXT1 and unraveled specific differences between XXT1 and XXT5 in the structural organization of their active sites. Structural characterization of three xyloglucan xylosyltransferases allowed us to produce solid evidence that XXT1 and XXT2 are not capable to complete xylosylation of glucan chain without contribution of XXT5. On the other hand, XXT5 requires the partially xylosylated glucan synthesized by the XXT1-XXT2 dimer as an acceptor substrate. Finally, we proposed the model of xyloglucan synthesizing complex where glucan chain exits binding site of glucan synthase and immediately shredded into binding site of XXT1 followed by XXT2 and finally by XXT5. The findings in this project significantly advance the knowledge about polysaccharide biosynthesis in plant Golgi and lays the strong foundation for the future research to fully understand the mechanisms of plant cell wall biosynthesis and the multiprotein complexes organization and functioning in plant Golgi apparatus.

Broader Impact of the project:

The knowledge about polysaccharide biosynthesis advanced by discovery of multiprotein complexes involved and further understanding of the key enzymatic mechanisms will open numerus opportunities in the areas of plant biotechnology and material sciences and engineering. For example, native and engineered protein-protein interactions can be exploit to generate novel synthetic complexes that can synthesize more desired cell wall polysaccharides to improve biomass properties tailoring for facile and complete conversion to biofuels or valuable bio-renewable materials. The knowledge of structures and mechanisms of catalysis for various glycosyltransferases can open broad opportunities in novel enzyme engineering to extend material synthesis, specifically of highly branched polysaccharide structures, which are unattainable for chemical synthesis alone. Demand for polysaccharide-based composites and carbohydrate modified materials is currently on the rise and their utilization will continue to diversify and expand. 

Four graduate, ten undergraduate and four high school students were trained during funding period and 11 peer-reviewed papers were published including 4 papers in Plant Physiology. All results obtained in this project were presented in numerous talks or poster presentations given by PI and students at the national and international scientific meetings, including European Cell Wall meetings 2013, 2016, Gordon Research Conferences 2012, 2015, International Cell Wall meeting 2014, EUROCARB meetings 2015, 2017, Annual meetings of American Society Plant Biologists 2015, 2017, 2018, and American Society of Biochemists and Molecular Biologists 2016, 2017, 2018.
